item.title: Between World Wars
item.description:
The period the first and second world war witnessed a staggering number of enormous changes in politics, art, technology and popular culture. Here are some links I’ve put together to begin examining the history more closely: Links Regarding the Interwar Period. I have left out links specifically focused on American history for the time being, in the interest of getting this page up and sticking to the world history focus of this site. About half the links are up today, and the rest should be up in the next week or so (I hope!). We are in the process of moving to San Francisco, and it has been time-consuming.

*I put the rest of the links (sans U.S. specific ones) up Thursday, Jan. 26th. We are moving this weekend, and it will be over soon!

item.description:

Links Regarding Globalization

I apologize for the impromptu break from working on the site for the past six weeks. I was preparing for contract employment, and of course there were the holidays and all the preparations they require. The end result is that I am working on a European history project, and that will tilt my work on this site in that direction for the next few months. The podcasts, coming in the next two months, will start with European history, instead of world, so that I can kill two birds with one stone.

item.title: Site Focus Adjustment
item.description:
It has taken me hundreds of hours to put up what is on here so far, and I know I am not close to done. The scope of the site to this point has been too wide - a hazard of studying the history of the world. What I have done today is remove all the human rights pages that did not yet have content, and I will leave that field to others more experienced than I.

Instead, I intend to focus on my areas of strength, modern world history, genocide and teaching. Those pages are about eighty-percent finished, and will hopefully be complete by the end of the year. 234 pages with initial content, and only 68 to go!

As you have probably noticed, the podcast is delayed. I have written the first two podcasts, a short introduction and one on why study history, but I am waiting on equipment, so recording probably won’t start until the first week of the new year.

item.title: Podcast Addition Coming Soon
item.description:
The whole podcast project I am going to attempt is, like this site, meant to illuminate the basic events of modern world history.

Topics will be covered in a thematic-chronological blend, starting with a very quick overview of the foundations of the modern world including religious, philosophical and civic ideas. Following that I will examine the Atlantic Revolutions of the late 18th and early 19th centuries, Industrialization, European Imperialism, Modern Ideologies, the Great War, the Interwar Period, World War II, the Cold War, the Holocaust and other Genocides, and Globalization.

The plan is to create introductions to each of these topics, and then cycle back through with more in-depth lectures, so although the breadth of this podcast stays the same, the depth will increase over time.

Additionally, I will try to post materials related to each podcast here on the site. You can find the related materials through links on each Podcast description, the Blog, the Site Guide, the Topics page, and of course the Search. If you know of a resource that would be helpful, please let me know.

item.title: The Holocaust
item.description:
The Holocaust may be the event that most clearly separated the twentieth century from the ones that came before it: it relied on racial ideology, industrialization, and totalitarian control in a way previous events of mass murder had not. I have put together a page of links to help with the understanding and teaching of the critical history, as well as other related pages listed below.
